case_vignette:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of progressive intermittent pain and swelling in both knees and right ankle and wrist for 3 months. She has been taking acetaminophen and using ice packs, both of which relieved her symptoms. The affected joints feel ""stuck” and difficult to move when she wakes up in the morning, but she can move them freely after a few minutes. She has also occasional mild eye pain that resolves spontaneously. Five months ago she was diagnosed with upper respiratory tract infection that resolved without treatment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows that the affected joints are swollen, erythematous, and tender to touch. Slit-lamp examination shows an anterior chamber flare with signs of iris inflammation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.6 g/dl
Leukocyte count 8,000/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 76%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 3%
Platelet count 360,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 36 mm/hr
Serum
Antinuclear antibodies 1:320
Rheumatoid factor negative
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having on-and-off pain and swelling in both my knees, right ankle, and wrist for the last 3 months.
How old are you?
I'm 4 years old.
Do you have any history of autoimmune diseases in your family?
I don't know about that.
Have you had any recent infections or fevers?
Five months ago, I had an upper respiratory infection but it got better without any treatment.
Are you taking any medications currently?
I've been taking acetaminophen and using ice packs for my pain and swelling.
Do you have any other medical conditions or relevant medical history?
No, just the upper respiratory tract infection from five months ago.
**Final Diagnosis:** Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 4-year-old child has been experiencing on-and-off pain and swelling in both knees, right ankle, and wrist for the last 3 months. The child had an upper respiratory infection five months ago, which resolved without treatment. Acetaminophen and ice packs have been used to manage the pain and swelling. There are no other medical conditions or medications to report, aside from the upper respiratory tract infection from five months ago.
